BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Natural avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs that are being formed by the storm force wind are prone to triggering in all aspects above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are numerous. Avalanche prone locations are to be found also in areas close to the tree line. As the precipitation becomes more intense natural avalanches are to be expected. In particular on north and east facing slopes avalanches can be released in the various layers of new snow and reach large size. Additionally in very isolated cases avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach very large size.

In addition a substantial danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes in all aspects in particular below approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 60 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The wind will be storm force. The westerly wind will transport the new snow significantly. The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The various wind slabs have bonded insufficiently with each other and the old snowpack. Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The new snow and wind slabs remain prone to triggering at elevated altitudes. With the end of the intense snowfall, the natural avalanche activity will decrease. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible on steep grassy slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Down to 1200 m snow has fallen in some regions. The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: On Friday the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Wind slabs are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. In particular on very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be released in the various wind slab layers and reach large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The wind was strong. The soft wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and stormy weather there will be an appreciable increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects, especially in areas close to the tree line and above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The fresh wind slabs can especially at their margins be released very easily. Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach large size in isolated cases. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.

A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

The conditions are sometimes critical for backcountry touring and other off-piste activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The violent wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Hardly any decrease in avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding avalanches require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are widespread and the danger is greater.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Up to 30 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. The wind will be strong to storm force over a wide area.
Fresh wind slabs will form also areas not adjacent to ridgelines. Wind slabs can be released easily, especially on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m. At transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
Some medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind.
From starting zones in which avalanches have already occurred in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanches can in isolated cases reach as far as the valley bottom.
In the Mont Blanc area In the late morning in some localities danger level 4 (high) will be reached.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
In the last five days on very steep grassy slopes several small and medium-sized avalanches occurred naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong to storm force over a wide area. The weather will be mild.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and stormy weather there will be an increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,, especially on steep shady slopes in areas close to the tree line, as well as above the tree line. They can especially at their margins be released very easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. The violent wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Hardly any decrease in avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 5 cm of snow, and up to 25 cm in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas above approximately 2200 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Dry avalanches can be released, mostly by large additional loads, especially on very steep shady slopes.
Several small and medium sized avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 1 (low) a little snow is lying in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong to storm force over a wide area. The weather will be mild.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and stormy weather there will be an increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,, especially on steep shady slopes in areas close to the tree line, as well as above the tree line. They can especially at their margins be released very easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. The violent wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Hardly any decrease in avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1500 m snow will fall on Friday in some localities. Up to 20 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2000 m.
As a consequence of new snow and stormy weather dry slab avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. Avalanches can be released by small loads.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2000 m. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
In particular on very steep slopes small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. In some places wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to gradual consolidation of the snowpack. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Above approximately 2500 m snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to significant settling of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the sometimes storm force wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the sometimes storm force foehn wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent. In particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain medium-sized slab avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases. Between approximately 2400 and 3000 m the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of the wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A little new snow above approximately 1000 m. The wind will be strong. These conditions will cause a slight rise in the danger of dry avalanches on steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, on steep shady slopes.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are rather small and can only be released in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found at high altitude and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The more recent wind slabs are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally at high altitudes. They are very small. The weather conditions from the early morning will give rise to moistening of the old snowpack. The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night and will already be soft in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable. From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are rather small and can be released by large loads in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be storm force adjacent to ridgelines. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack in all aspects.
